awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY 

The Division of Materials Research and the Physics Division contribute funds to this CAREER award to support research and education aimed at generating and exploiting quantum behavior at a macroscopic level. While quantum mechanics naturally operates at the microscopic regime, i.e. length scales much smaller than those we experience daily, stabilizing macroscopic quantum phenomena in large quantum systems can be exceedingly difficult due to the detrimental influence of the unavoidable interaction of the system with its surroundings. One possible approach to creating macroscopic quantum phenomena is based on recently discovered topological phases in condensed matter systems, which for fundamental reasons are effectively protected from the environment. The funded research is aimed at studying the rich variety of static and dynamical phenomena that arise from the interplay of these novel topological phases with conventional physics, such as electrostatic interactions, lattice vibrations, and material impurities. From recent experiments it is becoming clear that the physics of these systems cannot be understood without considering these conventional ingredients. More optimistically, apart from helping in understanding experiments, exploring the physics resulting from this interplay will likely lead to the discovery of new phenomena, which could influence the design of quantum computers. 

The education component includes disseminating knowledge on topological phases through an extended online course coupled to an open access forum on the subject that target graduate and undergraduate students; a concept version of the course has recently generated substantial interest from many countries. The PI will complement this kind of international outreach to a broad spectrum of budding scientists with outreach specific to local students aimed at a more basic level. In collaboration with colleagues at the University of Maryland, the PI will contribute in running a seminar series that aims to retain underrepresented minority students who transfer to the physics department at the University of Maryland from local community colleges.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY 

The Division of Materials Research and the Physics Division contribute funds to this CAREER award to support theoretical and computational research and education with the goal to extend the ideas of topological phases of matter and design robust quantum mesoscopic devices through the following steps: (1) analyzing the effects of phonons, interactions, and disorder on Majorana phases, (2) understanding the interplay of phase dynamics and topology in ultracold atomic gases, (3) stabilizing topological phases against disorder using quantum dot arrays, (4) using superconductors to generate phases beyond Majorana modes, (5) evaluating the robustness of excited topological states to interactions. Majorana modes, which are predicted to occur in certain topological phases of matter, are the most accessible examples of topological excitations. In addition to aiding the ongoing search for Majorana modes in solid-state systems, the research will provide insight into active areas of research in mesoscopic systems, topological materials, and quantum computation. The PI will use a combination of established analytical approaches, such as Keldysh perturbation theory, and state-of-the-art numerical techniques, to predict new phenomena relevant to mesoscopic quantum devices. The insight gained will be used to design new variants of topological materials. The intrinsic similarities of topological systems, e.g. the similarity of the toric code to quantum error correcting codes, will result in the research having impact on the quantum information community as well. 

The education component includes disseminating knowledge on topological phases through an extended online course coupled to an open access forum on the subject that target graduate and undergraduate students; a concept version of the course has recently generated substantial interest from many countries. The PI will complement this kind of international outreach to a broad spectrum of budding scientists with outreach specific to local students aimed at a more basic level. In collaboration with colleagues at the University of Maryland, the PI will contribute in running a seminar series that aims to retain underrepresented minority students who transfer to the physics department at the University of Maryland from local community colleges.

por.por_cntn:
The research activities of this project were directed towards guiding the experimental effort to control complex quantum materials using two guiding principles of topological superconducitvity and emergent gauge fields. The results obtained during this effort have contributed in a significant way to the broad progress in this area. 

The broad research effort in topological superconducitivity aims to discover phases that support Majorana fermions, which may be used to build topologically protected qubits using these superconductors. Researchers are exploring a large number of materials that are supporting these phases. One central challenge in this field is to separate signatures of the interesting topological superconducting phase from other trivial phases. The materials and systems being explored are new and therefore often demonstrate phenomena that have not been observed previously. However, these phenomena, at the same time are distinct in a subtle way from the signatures expected for topological superconductors. Two of our works (Huang et al Physical Review B 2018 and Sau et al Phys. Rev. B 2017) are both works exploring the subtleties of how novel but still non-topological systems may be mistaken for topological superconductors. These works have impacted the research community in directing them to be more careful in their search as is evident from the 74 and 34 citations these works have garnered in the past 5 years.

In a slightly different vein, another of our works Hsu et al Physical Review Letters 2020, studied the possibility that a (then) newly discovered superconductor, mono-layer WTe2, was an example of a so-called higher order topological superconductor. Our work was one of the earlier examples proposing a concrete material to be in such a phase and it also generated quite a bit of excitement, picking up about 74 citation in three years. WTe2 is an interesting material that supports a topological insulator phase at low density and transitions to becoming superconducting at slightly higher density. We showed that the most natural phase to occur in this situation is one which supports Majorana zero modes at the corners of the material. We hope this work will be eventually validated in experiments. In a somewhat earlier work published in Alavirad et al Physical Review Letters 2017, we showed that a Z3 parafermion, which has richer topological properties than the Majorana fermions, may be realized in an array of quantum dots in a fractional quantum Hall state. The fractional quantum Hall state is a very interesting phase of matter which have excitations with charges that are a fraction of an electron charge, despite the fact that this material (similar to any other real material) is made entirely of electrons. Such parafermions, if realized would eliminate the requirement for charge measurements to perform quantum gate operations. 

The works described above, which was part of my work in the area of topological superconductivity supported by this award, is a significant contribution to the research field of topological superconductivity. The ultimate goal of this area is to provide new and more robust and scalable components to realize qubits. Qubits are the basic building block of a quantum computers, which are expected to significantly affect the future of computation as well as sensing.

Other projects that the PI worked on using this award contributed to efforts of discovering new phases of matter. For example, the project Alavirad et al Physical Review B 2020, showed how results showing flat-band ferromagnetism from the 90's could be applied to understanding the orbital ferromagnetic phase of twisted bilayer graphene. This phase is a novel form of ferromagnetism that appears in a material with no spin-orbit coupling, which is key to stabilizing the spin in a ferromagnet.  Starting with this work, I have collaborated on several works in this area of complex phases in the new family of van der waals materials. A latest example of interesting collective phases proposed by us is fractonic dynamics in an ultra-cold gas of Lifshitz Bosons. This work currently appears in a 2023 arxiv preprint by authors Chou and Sau. Our study of this gas revealed that the domain-wall defects of this gas, that neccessarily exist at finite temperature, have extremely slow dynamics. As a result, this gas shows dessipative metal-like transport instead of superfluid transport. This is interesting because this metallic transport appears even in the absence of impurities, which are key for dissipative conduction in other one dimensional systems. The dissipative conduction is a signature of the slow dynamics of closed systems.

In summary, the research funded by this effort has contributed substantially to the community's understanding collective behavior of quantum systems in general and brought us closer to realizing reliable quantum information processing. The PI has also lectured to HBCU's and summer schools as well as online to motivate the next generation of students to participate in this effort.
